messages.subject: Re: tsuba id help (translation)
messages.msgSnippet: ... Strange, replying to your own posts :-) I was wondering since the plate is katchushi style S folded and well worked as stated above. The brass zogan is
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "alchemyst" <alchemyst@y...>

> Translation mystery solved. Now what school and period?
> With the well hammered, "S" folded plate, deep black patina
> and dark, rich brass zogan, I tend toward early Shoami
> or maybe Heianjo. The plate almost looks Saotome in quality.

Strange, replying to your own posts :-)

I was wondering since the plate is katchushi style "S" folded
and well worked as stated above. The brass zogan is well done
and as good as the kinko work of Nara or Ko-Nara. Could this
be a Nara or Ko-Nara piece on a Saotome plate?? (Probably
trying to read to much into it :-)

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: tsuba id help (translation)
messages.msgSnippet: ... Thanks to Prof. Alex Takeuchi, here s the full translation of the poem. In autumn collect the crops that were planted in spring and summer and store them
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "alchemyst" <alchemyst@y...>
wrote:
> Here is a translation of the characters on the
> tsuba that was given me by Sumie Kashima of
> Usagiya Sword in Japan. It seems it is a poem
> or haiku about winter, although an exact rendering
> wasn't possible.

Thanks to Prof. Alex Takeuchi, here's the full translation
of the poem.

"In autumn collect the crops that were planted in spring
and summer and store them in winter"

Referring to the endless cycles of nature, life and death, etc.
Neat :-)

Translation mystery solved. Now what school and period?
With the well hammered, "S" folded plate, deep black patina
and dark, rich brass zogan, I tend toward early Shoami
or maybe Heianjo. The plate almost looks Saotome in quality.

Any thoughts appreciated.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: tsuba id help (translation)
messages.msgSnippet: Here is a translation of the characters on the tsuba that was given me by Sumie Kashima of Usagiya Sword in Japan. It seems it is a poem or haiku about winter,
messages.messageBody:
Here is a translation of the characters on the
tsuba that was given me by Sumie Kashima of
Usagiya Sword in Japan. It seems it is a poem
or haiku about winter, although an exact rendering
wasn't possible.

Anyone familiar with a poem or haiku that would
fit this?

http://home.earthlink.net/~ttstein/kanji3.jpg

Thanks
Rich S

messages.messageBody:
All, I am looking to deschipher this Kanji ?????. I believe is says
Honami Mitsuyama ???, it is from a book I have just picked up written in
1965. I believe it is a limited edition ( 1000 copies ) and has I think
many oshigata in it. I cannot make out the title and I am waiting for it
to arrive so I will get better scans of it in the near future.

Does anyone know of this member of the Honami family, if he is/was one ?
and do you know what this book may be.

If this kanji does not work on this listserve, I can email it to you.

Rich

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id help
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, It depends on the guard.  It could be Shoami, or it could for example be Kaga-zogan as in the guard I posted yesterday.  How much earlier Mitsutada might
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
It depends on the guard. It could be Shoami, or it could for example be Kaga-zogan as in the guard I posted yesterday. How much earlier Mitsutada might have been working before Myoju isn't clear, but even with him we only have examples with nijimei. We don't know for sure whether or not he was associated with the Umetada. He could have been a Kyo-Shoami worker. I don't think that there are any fittings known to have been made by Myoju's father Shigetaka.

Sasano said:
"Umetada Myoju established the style and the fame of the Umetada name, which flourished greatly after his time. But he was not the first to make sword guards in the Umetada style. Now unknown craftsmen and a certain Mitsutada are known to have done this kind of work before Myoju. It seems likely that -- as the case with Shoami guards -- Umetada guards began being produced in the Muromachi period. Those that predate Myoju are based on Shoami ideas and are called Ko-Umetada, or old Umetada."

Even Sasano is making a rather narrow distinction between Ko-Umetada and Shoami.

Maybe evidence supporting the existence of Umetada workers predating Myoju will come to light.

On the other subject, I still can't see the three characters at the bottom of the guard very well. The character at the 3:00 position might be shu. I don't have much confidence that I could read the characters even if I got a better look at them.

Jim

Pardon a dumb question. If you don't use Ko-Umetada,
then what term is used for pre-Myoju tsuba in the
Umetada style?

Any idea what the rest of the Soshu script translates as?

Rich


[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id help
messages.msgSnippet: Hi Jim, Yes, I rather doubt that tsuba of yours would paper to Ko-Umetada now, but Saito san at Yashima still uses Ko-Umetada in his catalogues. I think it is
messages.messageBody:
Hi Jim,



Yes, I rather doubt that tsuba of yours would paper to Ko-Umetada now, but
Saito san at Yashima still uses Ko-Umetada in his catalogues. I think it is
a rather useful designation. With your tsuba, I think your call is more
appropriate. It doesn't look much like what is being called Ko-Umetada now,
other than the flat inlay. I also agree that getting Ko-Umetada on an NBTHK
kanteisho would be difficult. Have we been using that designation at all?



Gordon



-----Original Message-----
From: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...]
Sent: Tuesday, February 24, 2004 7:16 AM
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: tsuba id help



Rich,
I'm not sure if he was the originator of the term, but Mr. Sasano seemed to
be the main proponent of the idea of Ko-Umetada. I haven't found much
(any?) support for the idea in Japan these days. I have a guard here:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/heianjo.htm

second to last on the page, that Sasano-sensei attributed to late Muromachi
Ko-Umetada, but I don't think that a kanteisho in agreement with that could
be had today.

Jim



Jim and all -

Been doing some looking thru catalogs, references,etc.
Any possibility of this being a so-called Ko-Umetada piece??
It's vaguely similar to one in Haynes #7 that he calls
ko-Umetada (but then says there is really no such thing :-)
which I don't understand at all).

Rich S

Rich,
I'm not sure if he was the originator of the term, but Mr. Sasano seemed to be the main proponent of the idea of Ko-Umetada. I haven't found much (any?) support for the idea in Japan these days. I have a guard here:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/heianjo.htm

Jim

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id help
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, The seal script kanji on the upper right of the front side is KAN, cold or midwinter.  Also read samu(i), cold or chilly.  The seal script doesn t
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
The seal script kanji on the upper right of the front side is KAN, cold or midwinter. Also read samu(i), cold or chilly. The seal script doesn't particularly resemble the modern character, but it's an exact match in the Daijiten. I don't know what the next character is and it's hard to even see the rest in the photo.

I have seen a fair number of Heianjo-zogan guards with hitsu-ana shaped like that and irregularly surfaced plates. I can't say that I recall that inlay motif, but it is something that they'd be capable of doing. Maybe early Edo period. How thick is the plate?

Jim



I just purchased a tsuba that I have absolutely no
idea what it says, who made it or when - just fell
in love with it.

I'd appreciate any info that folks can provide.
First of all, what does the Kanji translate as?
The two gold Kanji: and then the other grass
script kanji (I think this is a prayer or poem -
anything other than "made in hong kong" :-)

Any help with translation, maker, period, etc
much appreciated.

http://home.earthlink.net/~ttstein/kanji.jpg

Thanks
Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] tsuba id help
messages.msgSnippet: Rich, I ll have to rush a bit here.  The design looks more like something derived from Kyoto and 3 mm is pretty thin for Owari.  Without seeing the metal in
messages.messageBody:
Rich,
I'll have to rush a bit here. The design looks more like something derived from Kyoto and 3 mm is pretty thin for Owari. Without seeing the metal in person it's hard to say with a guard like that. I've seen a few tsuba with classic Kyo sukashi designs that had purely Owari iron and no doubt were Owari, but I'm sure I would have said Kyo if I had only seen a face-on photo.

The guard that Curran posted is attributed to Owari, but mid Edo period. Most of the Owari characteristics of the iron are usually lost by then, but it looks like that one still has a bone or two. It's 5 mm thick and appears to have the squarish rim that you'd expect from Owari work. The design is also a bit more blocky. BTW, Owari-esq guards that have rounded rims are usually attributed to Shoami.

Some later Kyo and Owari guards can be difficult to separate. I can't think of an obvious alternative school for your guard. Enjoy cleaning it and studying it further.

Jim



Just got this tsuba. Needs some boning and fussing, but I'm wondering
about school. I think probably either Kyo-sukashi or Owari. However,
what may be iron bones on the mimi just look like rust bumps, so I
lean toward Kyo-sukashi. 76mm x 3mm.
Maybe some other school altogether?
Any thoughts appreciated.

http://gcclearn.gcc.vccs.edu/stein/tsuba.jpg

Thanks
Rich S
